Examples

Ivan Jacob Agaloos Pesigan

2021-03-20

Source: vignettes/examples.Rmd
examples.Rmd

This vignette presents four examples of generating Monte Carlo confidence intervals using the semmci package. The first example involves a simple mediation model. The second example involves a serial mediation model. The third example involves missing data. The fourth example involves the standardized indirect effect in a simple mediation model.

library(semmcci)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'semmcci'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     print
library(lavaan)
#> This is lavaan 0.6-8
#> lavaan is FREE software! Please report any bugs.

Example 1: The Simple Mediation Model

This is an example of a simple mediation model where x is the predictor, m is the mediator, and y is the dependent variable.

Data

n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n = n)
m <- 0.50 * x + rnorm(n = n)
y <- 0.25 * x + 0.50 * m + rnorm(n = n)
data <- data.frame(x, m, y)

Model Specification

The indirect effect is defined by the product of the slopes of paths x to m labeled as a and m to y labeled as b. In this example, we are interested in the confidence intervals of ab defined as the product of a and b using the := operator in the lavaan model syntax.

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b * m
  m ~ a * x
  indirect := a * b
  direct := cp
  total := cp + (a * b)
"

Model Fitting

We can now fit the model using the sem function from lavaan.

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 13 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         5
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Expected
#>   Information saturated (h1) model          Structured
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.297    0.037    8.118    0.000
#>     m          (b)    0.469    0.031   14.964    0.000
#>   m ~                                                 
#>     x          (a)    0.557    0.032   17.178    0.000
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 1.011    0.045   22.361    0.000
#>    .m                 1.029    0.046   22.361    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     indirect          0.261    0.023   11.283    0.000
#>     direct            0.297    0.037    8.118    0.000
#>     total             0.559    0.036   15.698    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

The fit lavaan object can then be passed to the mc function from semmcci to generate Monte Carlo confidence intervals for defined parameters.

out <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
print(out)
#> Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>             est     se   R ci_0.05 ci_0.5 ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp       0.2971 0.0382 100  0.2038 0.2077 0.2196  0.3613  0.3656   0.3673
#> b        0.4691 0.0307 100  0.4071 0.4077 0.4129  0.5302  0.5367   0.5401
#> a        0.5574 0.0305 100  0.4916 0.4919 0.5046  0.6166  0.6218   0.6225
#> y~~y     1.0110 0.0427 100  0.8998 0.9092 0.9237  1.0896  1.1229   1.1328
#> m~~m     1.0288 0.0432 100  0.9289 0.9380 0.9562  1.1111  1.1203   1.1211
#> x~~x     0.9773     NA  NA      NA     NA     NA      NA      NA       NA
#> indirect 0.2615 0.0249 100  0.2068 0.2103 0.2222  0.3146  0.3219   0.3228
#> direct   0.2971 0.0382 100  0.2038 0.2077 0.2196  0.3613  0.3656   0.3673
#> total    0.5586 0.0344 100  0.4864 0.4874 0.4969  0.6231  0.6424   0.6475

Example 2: The Serial Mediation Model

This is an example of a serial mediation model with two mediators where x is the predictor, m1 is the first mediator, m2 is the second mediator, and y is the dependent variable.

Data

n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n = n)
m1 <- 0.50 * x + rnorm(n = n)
m2 <- 0.15 * x + 0.50 * m1 + rnorm(n = n)
y <- 0.10 * x + 0.05 * m1 + 0.50 * m2 + rnorm(n = n)
data <- data.frame(x, m1, m2, y)

Model Specification

We can define several indirect effects in this example:

  • \(x \rightarrow m1 \rightarrow m2 \rightarrow y\)
  • \(x \rightarrow m1 \rightarrow m2\)
  • \(x \rightarrow m1 \rightarrow y\)
  • \(m1 \rightarrow m2 \rightarrow y\)

These indirect effects are defined using the := operator in the lavaan model syntax.

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b1 * m1 + b2 * m2
  m2 ~ a2 * x + k * m1
  m1 ~ a1 * x
  # x -> m1 -> m2 -> y
  a1kb2 := a1 * k * b2
  # x -> m1 -> m2
  a1k := a1 * k
  # x -> m1 -> y
  a2b2 := a2 * b2
  # m1 -> m2 -> y
  kb2 := k * b2
"

Model Fitting

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 16 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         9
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Expected
#>   Information saturated (h1) model          Structured
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.122    0.034    3.577    0.000
#>     m1        (b1)    0.064    0.034    1.906    0.057
#>     m2        (b2)    0.467    0.030   15.791    0.000
#>   m2 ~                                                
#>     x         (a2)    0.173    0.036    4.804    0.000
#>     m1         (k)    0.489    0.032   15.032    0.000
#>   m1 ~                                                
#>     x         (a1)    0.456    0.032   14.249    0.000
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 0.927    0.041   22.361    0.000
#>    .m2                1.060    0.047   22.361    0.000
#>    .m1                1.003    0.045   22.361    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     a1kb2             0.104    0.012    8.651    0.000
#>     a1k               0.223    0.022   10.341    0.000
#>     a2b2              0.081    0.018    4.596    0.000
#>     kb2               0.228    0.021   10.888    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

# The argument `par = TRUE` can be specified to use multiple cores for a faster implementation.
# The number of cores to use can be specified with `ncores`.
out <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
print(out)
#> Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>           est     se   R ci_0.05  ci_0.5 ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp     0.1220 0.0335 100  0.0196  0.0347 0.0586  0.1811  0.1968   0.2097
#> b1     0.0642 0.0336 100 -0.0164 -0.0132 0.0024  0.1311  0.1418   0.1443
#> b2     0.4670 0.0299 100  0.3823  0.3859 0.4031  0.5197  0.5255   0.5258
#> a2     0.1733 0.0340 100  0.1042  0.1056 0.1108  0.2376  0.2629   0.2687
#> k      0.4885 0.0318 100  0.4046  0.4047 0.4165  0.5499  0.5686   0.5690
#> a1     0.4560 0.0308 100  0.3715  0.3827 0.3983  0.5108  0.5275   0.5394
#> y~~y   0.9270 0.0414 100  0.8307  0.8336 0.8487  1.0038  1.0166   1.0188
#> m2~~m2 1.0598 0.0458 100  0.9245  0.9327 0.9758  1.1415  1.1670   1.1767
#> m1~~m1 1.0035 0.0515 100  0.8408  0.8669 0.9054  1.0820  1.1213   1.1528
#> x~~x   0.9799     NA  NA      NA      NA     NA      NA      NA       NA
#> a1kb2  0.1040 0.0115 100  0.0792  0.0799 0.0861  0.1281  0.1333   0.1334
#> a1k    0.2227 0.0205 100  0.1840  0.1840 0.1882  0.2637  0.2655   0.2658
#> a2b2   0.0809 0.0163 100  0.0453  0.0475 0.0533  0.1161  0.1229   0.1254
#> kb2    0.2281 0.0207 100  0.1764  0.1825 0.1934  0.2695  0.2846   0.2897

Example 3: Missing Data

This is an example of a simple mediation model with missing data.

Data

n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n = n)
m <- 0.50 * x + rnorm(n = n)
y <- 0.25 * x + 0.50 * m + rnorm(n = n)
data <- data.frame(x, m, y)

# Create data set with missing values.

miss <- sample(1:dim(data)[1], 300)
data[miss[1:100], "x"] <- NA
data[miss[101:200], "m"] <- NA
data[miss[201:300], "y"] <- NA

Model Specification

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b * m
  m ~ a * x
  ab := a * b
"

Model Fitting

We are using missing = "fiml" to handle missing data in lavaan. Since there are missing values in x, we also set fixed.x = FALSE.

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model,
  missing = "fiml",
  fixed.x = FALSE
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 14 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         9
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>   Number of missing patterns                         4
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Observed
#>   Observed information based on                Hessian
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.255    0.045    5.720    0.000
#>     m          (b)    0.454    0.038   11.866    0.000
#>   m ~                                                 
#>     x          (a)    0.532    0.034   15.490    0.000
#> 
#> Intercepts:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 0.077    0.035    2.171    0.030
#>    .m                -0.010    0.032   -0.316    0.752
#>     x                -0.026    0.032   -0.841    0.400
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 1.096    0.053   20.736    0.000
#>    .m                 0.929    0.045   20.806    0.000
#>     x                 0.916    0.043   21.254    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     ab                0.241    0.026    9.456    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

# The argument `par = TRUE` can be specified to use multiple cores for a faster implementation.
# The number of cores to use can be specified with `ncores`.
out <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
print(out)
#> Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>          est     se   R ci_0.05  ci_0.5  ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp    0.2546 0.0437 100  0.1625  0.1630  0.1646  0.3406  0.3487   0.3533
#> b     0.4539 0.0405 100  0.3535  0.3659  0.3866  0.5310  0.5414   0.5423
#> a     0.5320 0.0320 100  0.4482  0.4523  0.4691  0.5939  0.6067   0.6100
#> y~~y  1.0963 0.0577 100  0.9694  0.9736  0.9872  1.1966  1.2485   1.2800
#> m~~m  0.9285 0.0446 100  0.8100  0.8163  0.8317  1.0278  1.0400   1.0416
#> x~~x  0.9158 0.0408 100  0.8144  0.8257  0.8479  0.9896  1.0237   1.0303
#> y~1   0.0767 0.0342 100 -0.0065 -0.0016  0.0093  0.1504  0.1634   0.1678
#> m~1  -0.0102 0.0305 100 -0.0763 -0.0739 -0.0581  0.0608  0.0658   0.0678
#> x~1  -0.0265 0.0287 100 -0.1146 -0.1039 -0.0835  0.0218  0.0345   0.0376
#> ab    0.2415 0.0263 100  0.1878  0.1912  0.1963  0.2892  0.2969   0.3010

Example 4.a: The Standardized Simple Mediation Model - Version a

In this example, confidence intervals for the standardized indirect effect are generated using std.

Data

n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n = n)
m <- 0.50 * x + rnorm(n = n)
y <- 0.25 * x + 0.50 * m + rnorm(n = n)
data <- data.frame(x, m, y)

Model Specification

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b * m
  m ~ a * x
  indirect := a * b
  direct := cp
  total := cp + (a * b)
"

Model Fitting

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model,
  fixed.x = FALSE
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 12 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         6
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Expected
#>   Information saturated (h1) model          Structured
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.228    0.036    6.372    0.000
#>     m          (b)    0.531    0.032   16.702    0.000
#>   m ~                                                 
#>     x          (a)    0.550    0.031   17.700    0.000
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 1.036    0.046   22.361    0.000
#>    .m                 1.023    0.046   22.361    0.000
#>     x                 1.061    0.047   22.361    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     indirect          0.292    0.024   12.148    0.000
#>     direct            0.228    0.036    6.372    0.000
#>     total             0.520    0.035   14.723    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

# The argument `par = TRUE` can be specified to use multiple cores for a faster implementation
# for both `mc` and `std`.
# The number of cores to use can be specified with `ncores`.
mc <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
out <- std(mc)
print(out)
#> Standardized Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>             est     se   R ci_0.05 ci_0.5 ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp       0.1851 0.0258 100  0.1055 0.1072 0.1321  0.2218  0.2377   0.2497
#> b        0.4852 0.0291 100  0.4187 0.4220 0.4310  0.5408  0.5514   0.5541
#> a        0.4884 0.0272 100  0.4076 0.4161 0.4376  0.5403  0.5496   0.5505
#> y~~y     0.6426 0.0271 100  0.5874 0.5877 0.5903  0.6931  0.7017   0.7070
#> m~~m     0.7614 0.0315 100  0.6697 0.6742 0.6962  0.8312  0.8434   0.8528
#> x~~x     1.0000 0.0469 100  0.8960 0.8998 0.9130  1.0809  1.1251   1.1500
#> indirect 0.2370 0.0195 100  0.1754 0.1803 0.2052  0.2733  0.2783   0.2786
#> direct   0.1851 0.0258 100  0.1055 0.1072 0.1321  0.2218  0.2377   0.2497
#> total    0.4221 0.0253 100  0.3544 0.3606 0.3713  0.4622  0.4805   0.4956

Example 4.b: The Standardized Simple Mediation Model - Version b

In this example, confidence intervals for the standardized indirect effect are generated by specifying the standardized indirect effect as a derived parameter using the := operator.

Model Specification

The standardized indirect effect in a simple mediation model involves paths \(a\), and \(b\), and the standard deviations of \(x\) and \(y\). It is given by

\[\begin{equation} a b \frac{s_x}{s_y} \end{equation}\]

where

\[\begin{equation} s_x = \sqrt{ s_{x}^{2} } \end{equation}\]

and

\[\begin{equation} s_y = \sqrt{ c^{\prime 2} s_{x}^{2} + a^2 b^2 s_{x}^{2} + b^2 s_{e_{m}}^{2} + 2 c^{\prime} b a s_{x}^{2} + s_{e_{y}}^{2} } \end{equation}\]

where

\(s_{e_{y}}^{2}\) and \(s_{e_{m}}^{2}\) are the residual variances in the regression equations.

The standardized indirect effect can be defined using the := operator and the named parameters in the model.

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b * m
  m ~ a * x
  x ~~ var_x * x
  m ~~ var_em * m
  y ~~ var_ey * y
  std := a * b * (sqrt(var_x) / sqrt(cp^2 * var_x + a^2 * b^2 * var_x + b^2 * var_em + 2 * cp * b * a * var_x + var_ey))
"

Model Fitting

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model,
  fixed.x = FALSE
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 14 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         6
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Expected
#>   Information saturated (h1) model          Structured
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.228    0.036    6.372    0.000
#>     m          (b)    0.531    0.032   16.702    0.000
#>   m ~                                                 
#>     x          (a)    0.550    0.031   17.700    0.000
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     x       (vr_x)    1.061    0.047   22.361    0.000
#>    .m       (vr_m)    1.023    0.046   22.361    0.000
#>    .y       (vr_y)    1.036    0.046   22.361    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     std               0.237    0.018   13.275    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

# The argument `par = TRUE` can be specified to use multiple cores for a faster implementation.
# The number of cores to use can be specified with `ncores`.
out <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
print(out)
#> Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>           est     se   R ci_0.05 ci_0.5 ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp     0.2281 0.0364 100  0.1403 0.1442 0.1499  0.2899  0.2984   0.3046
#> b      0.5314 0.0326 100  0.4665 0.4723 0.4815  0.6057  0.6169   0.6236
#> a      0.5496 0.0324 100  0.4823 0.4838 0.4873  0.6020  0.6269   0.6466
#> var_x  1.0609 0.0446 100  0.9149 0.9338 0.9837  1.1397  1.1564   1.1681
#> var_em 1.0229 0.0443 100  0.9076 0.9155 0.9366  1.1063  1.1199   1.1251
#> var_ey 1.0356 0.0461 100  0.9246 0.9271 0.9385  1.1235  1.1453   1.1490
#> std    0.2370 0.0203 100  0.1912 0.1944 0.1985  0.2758  0.3057   0.3224
